title: Former UN General Assembly president charged in bribery scheme | Americas
text:
The United Nations General Assembly. Picture: REUTERS Related articles German prosecutors look into World Cup 2006 bribery claims Nigeria’s president enlists West to help recover stolen money Illicit trade of fish threatens economic stability, warns department NEW YORK — Former United Nations (UN) General Assembly president John Ashe was indicted on Tuesday by US authorities on charges of accepting more than a million dollars in bribes from Chinese real estate developers.
Mr Ashe, from Antigua and Barbuda, president of the assembly from September 2013 to September 2014, is accused of accepting money to promote the construction of a UN conference centre in Macau.
The 61-year-old is charged with accepting more than $1.3m from 2011 to 2014 from a group of five people, according to the indictment filed by Preet Bharara, the US attorney for the southern district of New York.
Mr Ashe is accused of hiding more than $1.2m in his income tax return.
Four other people were also charged on Tuesday, including the main suspect in the corruption ring, Ng Lap Seng, a wealthy Chinese real estate developer.
Another is Francis Lorenzo, a UN deputy ambassador from the Dominican Republic, who heads South-South News, a UN-accredited media outfit that reports on development issues.
The indictment alleges that the corruption ring relied on Mr Ashe and others to nail down the construction of a UN-sponsored conference centre in Macau at the cost of billions of dollars, as well as real estate projects in Antigua and Barbuda.
Mr Ashe presented the UN secretary general with a report stating that a conference centre in Macao was needed. It was never built.
AFP
